text:
Absolutely save the money and buy a dedicated laser printer.  The difference that you didn't mention when you compared the additional cost  of the 40W Bambu when compared to just buying the S1 is the cut size.  The camera is a nice feature, but with the alignment functions of the S1 it is minimal.  Having roughly twice the cut capacity, plus having a dedicated machine is going to completely offset the few hundred dollar difference.  Plus, XCS is a great software solution on it's own for beginners, but you can use LightBurn on the S1 when you grow beyond the limited feature set you get with Bambu Studio.

Additionally, I guarantee that the more you use the laser, the more dirty the inside of the 3D printer is going to get.  Take a picture of the inside of a P2 or P2S that gets daily use and you'll see what I mean.

Finally, the problem with having a shared machine is that when the H2D eventually has a failure, you lose all of your ability to work whereas if you have different machines, you can at least still do something.
video: Do Lasers Ruin 3D Printer‚Äôs? Bambu Lab H2D Laser R

text: Awkwardly, I wish they'd release the Laser edition without the laser module.  That may sound a bit odd, but the laser module is already shipped separately from the printer itself, and the Laser edition actually has other features that the non-Laser variants do not such as cutting and drawing.  Once the laser module is sold separately (I didn't find it on their store at the time of writing), then you could buy one when/if you wanted one.  They have talked about releasing an upgrade kit for the basic H2D, but given that the upgrade kit just puts you at the same level as a H2D Laser without the laser, I'd rather just buy that from the start.
video: Do Lasers Ruin 3D Printer‚Äôs? Bambu Lab H2D Laser R

text:
A company's ability to actually deliver is not really the concerning issue with Kickstarter. Kickstarter has no promises you will receive your product, and no refunds if you don't. The E1 is at nearly $40 million, and if the owners are secretly sh*theads like some crowdfunding campaigns have had, they can just pocket that money, close up shop, and retire. You can't even sue over it because you have to acknowledge the pledge is merely a donation.

Kickstarter never has been and never will be a pre-order platform. These companies need to run their pre-orders on their own sites to be credible, as kickstarter won't stop them. This project alone has made Kickstarter over $1 million in platform fees.

text: Update to delivery issues on this machine.  After contesting the charge on my credit card, whether that had anything to do with it or not (?), I did finally receive all ordered items.  The rotary was broken and AtomStack replaced that within a week.  With the exception of the 3rd mirror adjustment at the laser head - difficult to adjust due to the air assist tubing and the auto focusing wires disconnecting regularly (faulty connecter), oh and the decision not to provide free shipping so I'm still out $400, the machine is actually pretty good so far.  Pro: very robust metal build, this thing is solid! Proprietary software is good, I use both that and Lightburn, depending on what I am doing, and it is pretty precise.  Cons: difficult lens adjustment (laser head design could have been a bit better at little extra effort), rotary accessories are workable but made of plastic and don't have the same sturdiness of the laser (honestly, it's a beast!), but they work, just be gentle with them.  Support is decent.  I ordered during the Dragon Festival so that holiday gummed up the customer service a bit.  Expect delays in response due to  being on the other side of the world and the language barrier... some of the replies were difficult to decipher due to the language barrier.  Overall - I'm growing to really like this machine.
video: How Good is the Atomstack Hurricane Desktop Laser?

text:
Warning!

Cheapest "open laser" is not a professional equipment. The smoke, exhaust fumes can kill you - cancer is a likely possibility. The smell of exhaust fumes is unbearable. The burnt dust that is created during cutting or engraving is sticky and smelly. If you do not have a closed box laser with an activated carbon filter or at least an exhaust system outside the workshop, do not think about the laser business. These toys for a few hundred dollars are only suitable for amateur fun - no protection against the laser beam (risk of eye damage), toxic fumes, low power, low speed. Such a laser is only suitable for home-made - once in a while - for fun, for a hobby - provided that exceptional safety rules are observed.

text:
I've heard a couple/few YouTubers say they're thinking about getting the 'Pro' version of the HD1, but I haven't heard anyone say *why* they want the Pro over the less expensove 'Essential' or the more expensive 'Ultra'. Would you be willing to make a video talking about the peos and cons of each unit, as you see them?

I "backed" them and opted for the Ultra. I didn't just do it because "higher number = better" but because the Ultra has the MOPA fiber laser, and that's something I *think* I want...

I mean, I like having more settings to play with and I think the colors that can be put onto stainless steel and titanium look pretty cool, both things that having MOPA enables, but I haven't used either type of fiber laser so maybe I'd change my mind if I had more information... For instance, if the colors aren't *that* great in real life, maybe the extra cost won't be as valuable to me any longer.

text: Parts supply has been pretty terrible for ankermake printers for years. They do have some parts but it's very normal for them to go out of stock for months with 0 way to backorder. Anker also abandoned their slicer software and mobile app years ago. It was left in a pretty buggy state. They have also outsourced a lot of their support to members of their discord community and have almost no official interaction with customers there. Community members have had to build custom print profiles for orca because the default profiles were extremely poor and resulted in repeated print failures. There also have been multiple reports of customers returning defective printers under warranty and being sent back a barely functional refurbished unit with major problems. I am confident this product works well and based on what I see there's nothing else on the market similarly priced. Just keep in mind anker support is awful and they do not have any loyalty to you as a customer. They will abandon you the second this product appears to be a commercial failure.
video: $300 Ink?! The REAL Cost of the EufyMake UV Printe

text: I did some rough estimates and it looks like if you print just a few things a week the maintenance cost per month will be roughly $50.00 USD. That is assuming you only go through 1x Print head per year and 1x Cleaning Kit every 3 Months. That is not including ink costs per print as well we still do not know how much ink we lose during a line flush and or the machine maintenance cycle every few hours.
video: Is THIS the Future of Printing?  - eufyMake E1 UV

text: I have concerns regarding consumables the fact the machine can never be shut off without flushing the lines without knowing how much ink is lost and how many times you can flush the lines before the cleaner kit needs to be replaced. and also the machine does a cleaning cycle when not in use every few hours again not knowing ink loses and clean kit life. these are extremely expensive ink cartridges so losing ink so often to maintenance is worrisome let alone only a 3 month warranty on print heads which are extremely expensive. I was super excited and ready to jump in head first but after hearing about the ink lose and other consumables I'm struggling to see the value now, at least not without some more information on ink loss..

text: Other companies had better hope Bambu Labs does not fully get fully into this space because of their, money, integration, simplicity, and pricing.  They got into the 3D printing market a few years ago and now dominate because (like most of these laser companies) 3d companies were resting on their laurels and not trying to innovate instead focusing on trying to make a cheaper product.   Bambus new H2D 3D printer has a laser head you can add which surprised me.   I did not get it because I have an Xtools F1 and Onelaser but also why would I want all that dirt and smoke on my 3-D prints? But anyway other companies had better step up in the prosumer space because if they get serious and come out with a lidar, 5 camera, AI controlled big boy I would bet small companies will be out of business within a few years. As they already have all this tech in their high end printers and are now toying with laser heads.

text:
Working with cutting lasers about 10 years ago for glass. We used mirrors to transmit the beam, with a focus setup on the head to adjust the final focus point and to compensate for the fluctuating movement.

Other setups used a scan head, 2 mirrors that would adjust x,y, with another focal lens to adjust for z as x,y changed the z distance changed from the point of emittance.

The distance was a few feet from the working surface.

Is there a reason why no one builds diodes with "moving mirrors" like the CO2 lasers? 
I mean... just replace the tube with a diode and you can have the thing running much faster than by dragging the diode around all the time.
Why is this not a thing?

text:
Being in school photography since 2016, I have lots of experience with printers. And the of the biggest issues are with the print head and ink.

- Ink tends to dry out and clog. Any news on how thos is handled with the resin? I known it's UV resin and doesn't exactly dry out. But over time, it can still happen. Colored resin isn't just resin. There's still ink particles that can clump up when sitting idle.

- The print head is easily the most annoying component. They shift and rare out over time. They're not easy nor cheap to replace. And it's not like we can just call a repair shop to come over and fix this one.

- I've ran into far too many issues with the ink spilling all over the printhead and down onto the paper and internal components. How would that be addressed with this printer? Resin would be a lot more difficult to remove than traditional liquid or powder ink.

- To add to that, how easy is it to repair/place the print bed components? The belt, the gears, etc?

text: I'm about ready to buy this, but if I heard this right. If the printer sits unused for more than 72 hours a deep cleaning cycle must be used. Meaning, you must constantly be banging out prints or you eat up cleaning cartridges for simply sitting idle. I'm on edge about buying this machine because everyone talking good about it got it for free sponsored, and isn't exactly giving a truly bias opinion. Eufymake also dumped on their customers in the past launching products then killing support and dropping the product line all together. The only hope I have is that adam savage from tested used this so I'd hope it would mean it would be continuously used. If the self cleaning cartridges were cheap then not much of an issue. If some other china company sells cheaper inks, great, many headaches cost wise solved.
